content:
Diagnosis:	Papillary renal cell carcinoma type 2

Management:	15 March 2024 Partial right nephrectomy

Histology:	pT1b (4.2cm) papillary renal cell carcinoma type 2, mid pole of right kidney, margins clear

Molecular:	MET amplification detected

Current Situation:	Post-operative follow-up

I reviewed [redacted name] today following his recent partial nephrectomy. He has made an excellent recovery from surgery with minimal post-operative pain and good wound healing. His renal function remains stable with creatinine 98 μmol/L (pre-operative baseline 92). He has returned to most normal activities though still avoiding heavy lifting as advised.

His original presentation was with an incidental 4.2cm right renal mass detected during ultrasound for gallstone assessment. Subsequent CT confirmed a solid enhancing lesion in the mid pole of the right kidney with no evidence of local invasion or metastatic disease. He underwent partial nephrectomy on 15th March 2024 with uncomplicated recovery.

Histology confirmed a type 2 papillary renal cell carcinoma, pT1b with clear margins. Molecular testing has shown MET amplification. Given the stage and complete resection, no adjuvant therapy is indicated at present.

The plan is for surveillance imaging with CT chest/abdomen/pelvis in 6 months' time, then annually if stable. I have also arranged baseline blood tests including renal function, calcium, and liver function tests. We will review him following the next scan. I have provided information about symptoms to watch for and contact details for the specialist nursing team.
